glossdef.para: A task that is scheduled by a system administrator using &susemgr; to be performed on one or more client systems. For example, an action can be scheduled to update the kernel packages on all the systems in a selected group.

&susemgr; Management and Provisioning customers can generate activation keys through the &susemgr; Web site. Each unique key can then be used to activate (register) a client system (either &slea; or &rhela;), entitle the system to &susemgr;, subscribe the system to specific channels, and subscribe the system to &susemgr; system groups through the command line utility rhnreg_ks from the bootstrap script.
The activation key administrator manages the collection of activation keys. A user with this role assigned can modify and delete any key within the organization.

A base channel is a type of that consists of a list of packages for a specific architecture and &suse; release. For example, all the packages in &sls; 11 SP1 for the x86 architecture make a base channel.
A that pertains to a bug fix.

Bugzilla is an online application () that allows users to communicate directly with the developers. In Bugzilla, users can submit bug reports and feature requests for &sle; and related open source packages.
A Certificate Authority distributes digital signatures to users as part of a public key infrastructure for encrypted authentication and communication.

A channel is a list of software packages. There are two types of channels: base channels and child channels. Channels are used to choose packages to be installed on client systems. Every client system must be subscribed to one and can be subscribed to one or more .

A user role with full access to channel management capabilities. Users with this role can create channels, assign packages to channels, clone and delete channels. This role can be assigned by an organization administrator through the Users tab of the Web interface.
A child channel is a associated with a but contains extra packages.
A system that is registered with &susemgr;. Also known as registered system.

A client component in XML format that is stored in the /etc/sysconfig/rhn/systemid file on registered systems. &susemgr; verifies this certificate to authenticate the registered system before each connection. This certificate is issued by &suse; and passed to the system as part of the registration process. It includes unique information about the registered system to avoid fraudulent use.

Similar to a , except the information is delivered via email. If the email notifications option is selected, notifications are sent for every . The email includes the type of the toms 2010-11-30: Correct following terms? patch alert, summary of the patches, description of the patch, and a list of systems affected by the alert.
A that pertains to a package enhancement request.
One of &suse;'s service level offerings. It has more features than the update service level, including user management, system groups, and enhanced system details.

Monitoring consists of two components: the monitoring system and the monitoring scout. The monitoring system is installed on the &susemgr; and performs backend functions such as storing monitoring data and acting on it. The monitoring scout runs all the probes and collects monitoring data.
Users with this role assigned can schedule probes and supervise the monitoring infrastructure (only available on monitoring-enabled systems).
An email address to which &susemgr; monitoring messages will be sent.

A user role with the highest level of control over an organization's &susemgr; account. Organization administrators can add users, systems, and system groups to the organization as well as remove them. They can also edit details of their organization's users, for example, to grant them certain permissions by assigning roles. Each organization must have at least one organization administrator.
All software in &sle; is divided into software packages. Software updates are released in the form of RPM packages that can be installed on a &sle; system.

A client application for &rhel; client systems that allows users to retrieve and install all updated packages for the client system on which the application is run. From &rhel; 5 on, this application replaces the &updagent; (&up2date;) that was shipped with former &rhel; versions.

&suse; provides fixes for security issues and bugs as well as package enhancements for &sls; in the form of patches. These contain a topic, Bugzilla bug IDs, relevant releases/architectures, and the solutions including required RPMs, and file checksums for verification.
Each &suse; is based on the &sle; patch list.

Security issues and bugs are reported by &suse; engineers and the Linux community via Bugzilla, which tracks the bug reports for each issue. &suse; engineering evaluates the reports, resolves the bugs, and generates new RPM packages. After the &suse; quality assurance team has tested new packages, the patch is complete and is placed on the &suse; file server for distribution and installation.

An alert updates packages containing &suse; patches available for one or more systems within an organization. There are three types of patch alerts: security alerts, bug fix alerts, and enhancement alerts.
A set of criteria that is either a template or a set of values assigned to a system that is used to measure the performance of a system.
The measure of a system's adherence to a probe's defined criteria. States include: OK, Warning, Critical, Pending, Unknown
Collection or group of &susemgr; monitoring probes.
One of the &ncc; service level offerings. It has more features than the Management service level, including autoinstalling, reconfiguring, tracking, and reverting systems.
See .

A client application for &rhel; client systems that allows users to retrieve and install all updated packages for the client system on which the application is run. The application also includes functionality to register the client with &susemgr;. Use the Red Hat Update Agent Configuration Tool to configure its preferences.
See .

A software package manager that was developed by Red Hat Inc. It can be used to build, install, query, verify, update, and uninstall software packages. All software updates from &susemgr; are delivered in RPM format.

Each &sle; system has an RPM database that stores information about all the RPM packages installed on the system. This information includes the version of the package, which files were installed with the package, a brief description of the package, the installation date, and more.
Deliver the RPM packages based on the list to a client system without user intervention. If this feature is selected, packages are delivered via the running on the client system.
A that pertains to system security.
A &suse; subscription service. Different service levels offer different features of &susemgr;. There are three paid service levels currently available: update, management, and provisioning.
Siblings are virtual guests running on the same host. Virtual guests that run on separate hosts are not siblings.

A user role that has the highest level of control in the &susemgr; Web interface. A &susemgr; administrator can assign the &susemgr; administrator role to other users. However, without also having the role of an organization administrator, a &susemgr; administrator cannot edit user details for organization users. An organization must have at least one &susemgr; administrator assigned.

The bootstrap script (bootstrap.sh) is a script on your &susemgr; server which has to be enabled in Admin&susemgr; ConfigurationBootstrap Script before its initial use. It is executed on clients and collects all information needed by the &susemgr; server like and . The script establishes a connection to your server and registers the clients.

The &susemgr; client daemon (rhnsd) that periodically polls
for scheduled actions.
The System Directory section of &susemgr; allows an organization to divide its client systems into system groups. Only a can add systems to an organization.
The system group administrator can create new system groups, delete any assigned systems from groups, add systems to groups, and manage user access to groups.
A unique string of characters and numbers that identifies a registered system. It is stored in the system's .

Contains hardware and software information about the client system. The profile is created during the registration process and stored on the &susemgr; server. The software information is a list of RPM packages and their versions installed on the client system. The system profile is used to determine every relevant to each client system.
Interface that allows users to perform actions on multiple systems. Actions include applying patch updates, upgrading packages, and adding/removing systems to/from system groups.

A traceback is a detailed error message for troubleshooting &susemgr;. &susemgr; automatically generates tracebacks when a critical error occurs and sends mails the individual(s) designated in the &susemgr; configuration file.
One of the &ncc; service level offerings.
Any of the virtual instances running on the virtual host, under the control of the hypervisor. Also referred to as domain U or domU.
The physical system on which the hypervisor and all guest systems are running. The virtual host may also be referred to as domain 0, or dom0.
A graphical user interface for updating software packages on &sle; systems.
A command line tool on &rhel; client systems, used to retrieve and install new or updated packages.
See .
A command line tool on &sle; systems. Use zypper to install, update, or remove software packages, and to manage repositories from the command line.
